subject: Methane
object: GHG
source_paper: Copy of A. Priyadarsini et al. 202320251115.pdf
source_text: Methane  is  the  smallest  of  the  hydrocarbon  family  in  its  most reduced form, which means it is packed with potential energy. It is also a major greenhouse gas (GHG) which is also called a short-term enforcer, i.e. it persists in the atmosphere for shorter duration, as compared to carbon dioxide (CO2) that can stay in atmosphere for thousand years, but its heating effect is much more potent than that of CO2. Thus, even with a shorter lifespan, methane has 28 -34 times higher global warming potential over a period of 100 years than that of CO2  due to its higher solar  radiation  capturing  efficiency  (Priyadarsini  et  al.,  2020).
llama3.2_3b_text_justification: The relation "is a major greenhouse gas" is directly stated in the source sentence, and the entity boundaries (subject "Methane" and object "GHG") are correctly identified.

subject: Methanotrophs
object: Dairy and cattle industries
source_paper: Copy of A. Priyadarsini et al. 202320251115.pdf
source_text: Major  sources  of  methanotrophs  include  agricultural  rice  fields, natural gas fields, dairy and cattle industries, etc. The difference in the  rate  of  production  and  emission  can  be  explained  by  methane oxidation by the methanotrophs present in the oxic regions of the rice roots  and  rhizospheres  (Conrad  and  Rothfuss,  1991). The  conversion efficiencies  of  transported  methane  by  methanotrophs  remain  in  the range of 70 -95 % in the soil-water interface (Epp and Chanton, 1993; Gilbert  and  Frenzel,  1995). The  rice  field  rhizosphere  community comprises of type I and type II methanotrophs. In fact, no Type I methanotrophs had been isolated from rice rhizosphere, rice roots, bulk soil or floodwater and  only  their  presence  was  confirmed  using  molecular  techniques (Dianou et al., 2012; Pandit et al., 2016; Takeda et al., 2008). Several methanotrophs  with pmoA lineages  from  rice  paddy  cluster  (e.g., RPC1 -3)  have  been  detected  but  remain  uncultured  till  date  (Knief, 2015; Lüke et al., 2014). Methanol production capability of these methanotrophs is yet to be studied. Thus, rice field was chosen for this study since  they  are  a  breaming  source  of  methanotrophs  and  they  are commonly found across India.
llama3.2_3b_text_justification: The relation "are sources of" is directly stated in the source sentence, and the entity boundaries (subject and object) are correctly identified. The extracted relation accurately represents the relationship between methanotrophs and dairy and cattle industries as sources of methane production.
mistral_7b_text_justification: The relation is accurately represented in the sentence as it mentions "Major sources of methanotrophs include... dairy and cattle industries". However, the faithfulness rating is lower because the focus of the sentence is not solely on the dairy and cattle industries as a source of methanotrophs. The subject and object boundaries are correctly identified in the sentence.
llama3.1_8b_text_justification: The relation is accurately represented in the sentence, with "methanotrophs" being correctly identified as the subject and "dairy and cattle industries" as the object. The entity boundaries are also perfectly identified, with no overlap or underlap between the subject and object positions.

subject: Methane
predicate: is the most widely used substrate employed in cultivating this organism
object: M. trichosporium
source_paper: Copy of Adegbola thesis High Density Cultures20251113.pdf
source_text: M. trichosporium is  an  aerobic, obligate methanotroph that can only utilize C1- carbon sources  such  as  methane  and  methanol  as  primary  growth  substrates. It  is  a  Type  II methanotroph  producing  both  soluble  (sMMO)  and  particulate  (pMMO)  forms  of methane  monooxygenase. Methane is the most widely used substrate employed in cultivating this organism.

subject: Methane
object: half of n
source_paper: Copy of A. Priyadarsini et al. 202320251115.pdf
source_text: The moles of headspace gas (equimolar mixture of air and methane) can be calculated using ideal gas equation: PV = nRT. GLYPH<0> 1 , T = 303 K, the total number of gas moles (n) in the headspace are 6.64 mmoles, half which accounts for methane. Considering the metabolic stoichiometry of 1 mol of methanol per mol of methane,  the  total  percentage  consumption  of  methane  (or  in  other words methanol yield per mole of methane) is: 2.6/3.32 = 0.783 or 78.3 %.
llama3.2_3b_text_justification: The relation "makes up" is accurately represented in the sentence, as it states that half of the total number of gas moles accounts for methane. The faithfulness rating is 5 because the relation is directly stated in the source sentence without any additional information or assumptions. The boundary quality rating is 4 because the subject and object boundaries are generally correct, but there might be some minor issues with the exact wording or phrasing (e.g., "half which accounts for methane" could be more precisely worded).

source_text: It is an α -proteobacterium in the family Methylocystaceae that  is  representative  of  all  Type  II  methanotrophs.
